body_content.explanation: to move a train or carriage onto a different track in or near a station using a special railway engine designed for this purpose
to move someone or something from one place to another, usually because that person or thing is not wanted, and without considering any unpleasant effects:
examples: I spent most of my childhood being shunted (about) between my parents who had divorced when I was five.
He shunts his kids off to a camp every summer.
Viewers are sick of their favourite sitcoms being shunted to later times to make way for live sports coverage.

body_content.explanation: a hole or passage that allows liquid to move from one part of the body to another, either found naturally in the body or put into the body in an operation:
examples: The doctor had trouble finding a vein to insert the shunt.
An estimated 50% of all shunts fail within two years, requiring further surgery to replace the shunts.

body_content.explanation: a car accident in which one vehicle drives into the back of another:
examples: The accident was his second high-speed shunt.
He gave me a lift last night because I had a little shunt in my new car.
